caption: The National Hurricane Center predicts an active 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, with an 85% chance of above-normal activity, including 17-25 named storms, 8-13 hurricanes, and 4-7 major hurricanes. Florida faces a high risk, with a 96% chance of being impacted by a named storm and a 75% chance of a hurricane. Colorado State University and AccuWeather forecasts suggest the season could be one of the busiest on record due to favorable conditions like warm Atlantic waters and reduced wind shear. Enhanced tools and new models will aid in forecasting and communication.

June marks the beginning of hurricane season, with most early storms forming in the Gulf of Mexico or the western Atlantic. While June hurricanes are rare, tropical storms can still bring significant impacts, especially along the southeastern U.S. coast and the Gulf. Historically, only about 6% of all Atlantic Basin storms occur in June, with August, September, and October being the busiest months. Last June saw unusual activity, including three named storms forming, with one taking a rare backward path in the Gulf of Mexico.

As we head into the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, experts forecast an unprecedented and extraordinary period ahead. With warmer waters expected to fuel stronger storms, now is the time to take action and prepare for what's to come. The ocean has absorbed significant heat over decades, setting the stage for potentially intense hurricanes. For the next 30 minutes, we will help you get ready by detailing the changes impacting South Florida, including who needs to evacuate and the essential supplies you need. Join Next Weather meteorologists as we guide you through preparing the ultimate hurricane kit, explore innovative solutions for keeping the lights on, and delve into the role of AI in forecasting. Plus, meet the brave hurricane hunters who fly into the eye of the storm to provide crucial information. Stay with us as we navigate Hurricane 2024 and what's next. Remember, don't be scared, be prepared.

The Disaster Preparedness Sales Tax Holiday runs from June 1 through June 14, with a second period from August 24 to September 6. These tax-free periods are a great time to stock up on crucial supplies without the added cost of sales tax. By planning ahead, you can avoid the last-minute rush and ensure you have everything you need to stay safe during a hurricane or other emergencies.

Governor Ron DeSantis discussed hurricane preparedness in Florida, highlighting a tax-free holiday from June 1-14 for essential items like generators, pet supplies, and tarps. Emphasizing the need for a seven-day emergency kit, he assured readiness for the predicted "above-normal" hurricane season. DeSantis also awarded $7.5 million to Lee County for disaster response infrastructure.

ISeeChange, with a $685,000 investment from the Knight Foundation, uses AI to help Miami tackle climate change by enabling residents to report flooding, heat, and pollution in real time. This data aids local governments in developing effective mitigation strategies. Since 2020, ISeeChange has secured over $20 million for stormwater projects in Miami and improved response times during storms. The app fosters community engagement, ensuring solutions are informed by those most affected. This partnership is part of Knight's broader effort to promote urban resilience.

Florida prepares for its annual rainy season, and we stand vigilant, tracking potential tropical disturbances lurking in the Caribbean and along coastal waters. With warm ocean temperatures and minimal wind shear, conditions are ripe for storm intensification. Although the risk of tropical development is currently low, the looming threat of heavy downpours brings hope for drought relief. As hurricane season approaches, it's crucial to stay informed and prepared for any eventualities. Stay tuned for updates and heed safety measures to ensure resilience against potential storms.

With the Atlantic hurricane season underway, Florida residents must prepare their trees and yards for potential storms. As forecasters predict an active season due to an overheated Atlantic Ocean and La NinÌƒa, readiness is paramount. Trim trees to reduce wind resistance, secure loose items, and stake young trees to prevent uprooting. Take precautions with delicate plants and consider removing brittle trees prone to damage. Plant storm-safe species like cabbage palm and coconut palm to fortify your landscape. Stay informed and heed expert advice to safeguard your property during hurricane season.

LawnStarter's 2024 ranking of the Most Hurricane-Vulnerable Counties highlights the urgent need for hurricane preparedness in Florida, where Broward, Palm Beach, and Miami-Dade counties are among the top five most at risk. Floridians are advised to have evacuation plans, secure flood insurance, and fortify homes against wind and flooding. Regular roof inspections, gutter maintenance, and hurricane-resistant landscaping can mitigate damage. With a busy hurricane season predicted, staying informed through NOAA and FEMA and being ready for quick response and recovery are crucial. This report underscores the importance of proactive measures to protect homes and families in Florida.

A tropical deluge is set to drench Florida, bringing substantial rainfall and the potential for flooding, particularly in South Florida. This influx of moisture, moving north from the Caribbean, will cool scorching temperatures and could alleviate drought conditions in Southwest Florida. Despite the flooding risk, the rain offers relief from the recent heat and dry spell.

Gear up for the upcoming hurricane season with a community forum featuring expert insights and strategies. Learn from seasoned emergency managers and weather specialists about preparation tactics, evacuation procedures, and post-storm recovery plans. Don't miss this opportunity to ensure your safety and readiness amidst forecasts predicting heightened storm activity. Join us for an essential discussion aimed at empowering residents to face the challenges of the storm season ahead.

Florida faces significant weather developments as Invest 90-L moves off the coast. The National Hurricane Center (NHC) monitors two potential tropical systems. Invest 90-L, with a 20% formation chance, continues to bring heavy rain. Another disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico may develop, with a 40% formation chance next week. Flooding remains a concern.
